title: 108_s837
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission on the Accountability and Review of Federal Agencies Act" and establishes a Commission. The Commission on the Accountability and Review of Federal Agencies is established with 12 members appointed by the President. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are designated from among the members. Members serve for the life of the Commission and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Meetings must be held within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Commission on the Accountability and Review of Federal Agencies, consisting of 12 members appointed by the President, must hold its first meeting once all members are appointed. Subsequent meetings will be called by the chairperson. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for meetings, but hearings can be held with fewer members present. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with evaluating agencies and programs, recommending realignment or elimination, and proposing legislation. The criteria include identifying duplicative functions within agencies or programs. The Commission evaluates agencies and programs, recommending realignment or elimination based on wasteful spending, mismanagement, outdated purposes, or failure to meet objectives. The President must establish a systematic method for assessing agency programs' effectiveness and accountability within a year of enacting the Act. Assessments of at least half of all programs covered must be submitted to the Commission using this method, which should recognize different program types and primarily assess performance goals. The President must establish a method for assessing program effectiveness and accountability, including performance measures and financial management. The Commission will review and accept the method before implementation. Assessments will be considered when evaluating programs, and common performance measures will be identified for similar programs within a year of enacting the Act. The Commission must submit a report to the President and Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The report includes a plan with supporting documentation and proposed legislation. Savings from the plan implementation must be used to support domestic programs or pay down the national debt. The proposed legislation aims to relocate federal employees affected by position eliminations due to plan implementation. The proposed legislation aims to relocate federal employees affected by position eliminations due to plan implementation. SEC. 4. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission has the power to conduct hearings, issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence, and require the production of relevant materials for investigations. Subpoenas must be signed by the Commission's chairperson. The Commission has the power to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence, enforce them through court orders, and obtain information from Federal agencies as needed. The Commission has the authority to request information from federal agencies, use the United States mails, and accept gifts or donations. SEC. 5. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. SEC. 5. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Compensation of Members: Non-federal members do not receive compensation, while federal officers or employees serve without additional compensation. Travel Expenses: Members are allowed travel expenses as per authorized rates. Staff: The chairperson of the Commission may appoint staff. The chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The executive director can determine their own compensation, not exceeding the maximum rate for a GS-15 position. The executive director and Commission personnel are federal employees under title 5, United States Code. Members of the Commission are not included. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured. The chairperson of the Commission may procure temporary and intermittent services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, at rates for individuals which do not exceed the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay prescribed for level V of the Executive Schedule under section 5316 of such title. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting the report under section 3(f). Congressional consideration of reform proposals will follow. In this section, an implementation bill is defined as a bill introduced without modification containing proposed legislation from a report. A calendar day is defined as a day when either House is not in session due to an adjournment of more than 3 days. On the first calendar day when both Houses are in session, a single implementation bill shall be introduced in the Senate by the Majority Leader. Implementation bills introduced in the Senate by the Majority Leader and designated Members, and in the House of Representatives by the Speaker and designated Members, shall be referred to appropriate committees for jurisdiction. Implementation bills referred to committees in the House of Representatives can be reported without amendment. If a committee fails to report the bill within 15 days, it will be discharged and placed on the calendar for floor consideration. Once reported or discharged, the bill can be considered at any time. After an implementation bill is reported or discharged by a committee in the House of Representatives, any Member can move to proceed to its consideration. This motion is privileged, not debatable, and not amendable. If agreed to, the bill becomes the unfinished business. An implementation bill shall remain the unfinished business of the respective House until disposed of. Amendments are not allowed in the Senate or the House of Representatives. Debate on the bill is limited to 10 hours, divided equally between supporters and opponents. Further debate limitations and certain motions are not allowed. Voting on final passage follows the debate. The implementation bill shall remain unfinished business until voted on for final passage after a 10-hour debate with limited amendments and no further debate limitations or motions allowed. Appeals on procedural rulings by the Chair shall be decided without debate. Coordination with the other House's implementation bill follows specific procedures. The implementation bill of the other House shall not be referred to a committee. The procedure for the House receiving the bill will be the same as if no bill had been received, but the final passage vote will be on the other House's bill. This section is enacted by Congress as part of the rules of each House for the procedure to be followed. The implementation bill described in subsection (a) must follow specific procedures in the House, superseding other rules if inconsistent. Each House has the constitutional right to change its rules regarding procedures at any time. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2004 through 2006 is provided for carrying out this Act.
